doc.field: Germany has a new head of state

Johannes Rau was sworn in today as Germany's eighth president. In his inaugaral speech, the former prime minister of North Rhine Westphalia described his goals of his period of office. Rau wants to support solidarity and tolerance in the society. He wants to play a double role: he will speak for all Germans on one hand, and wants to help minorities to gain attention on the other hand.
Bundestag brings its residence in Bonn to an end

Today the German Bundestag had its last plenary meeting in Bonn. On this occassion, former Chancellor Helmut Kohl gave his first speech since his voting out last September. Kohl thanked the city of Bonn for its "servive to the nation". He said that the freest, most humane, and most social state which German soil has ever seen was created in Bonn. At noon, Bundestag and Bundesrat members assembled for a joint meeting during which Johannes Rau was sworn in.
Catholic consultation of pregnant women in conflict under discussion

The Federal Government and its Laender talked today about the role of the catholic consultation of pregnant women in conflict. The core question was whether the consultation certificates with the addition of it being prohibited would allow a legal abortion. The Federal Government and its Laender do not see any illegalities. Bavaria, Baden-Wuerttemberg, and Saxony had no problems with the new consultation certificates. Other Laenders, however, doubt unbiased consultations by the catholic church. This will be now clarified with the bishops.
Martin Bangemann takes leave of absence as EU commissioner

Martin Bangemann was given leave of absence as EU-commissioner. The FDP-EU-politician was in charge of industry politics and telecommunication. Yesterday he asked to be released from his duties as soon as possible because he wants to work for the Spanish company Telefonica. This caused annoyance in the EU-commision as Bangemann changes into excatly that area for which he had been responsible for for many years.
Further attacks on Turkish facilities

Further attacks on Turkish facilities were registered last night also in cities in North Rhine Westphalia and Baden-Wuerttemberg. Damage was caused but no people were harmed. The attackers0 are most likely followers of the illegal Turkish workers' party PKK. Two days ago, Turkey sentenced their leader Oecalan to death. The sentence is as yet not final.
Dismissal without notice due to rassism authorised

The Federal Court for Work has decided that a dismissal without notice due to rassism is permissible. The case is about an apprentice of the Berlin municipal cleaning department who put a provoking sign on the desk of a Turkish collegue; together with others he sang neonazi songs. The response of the Berlin municipal cleaning department was his dismissal without any advance notice - rightly, as the Federal Court decided today.
Arrest in connection with Merseburg bombing

Three days after the bombing in Merseburg, police arrested a main suspect in Poland. The 31-year-old German is now in jail in Breslau. A request for extradiction has come in. According to the police, the man is a nightclub owner and head of a motorcycle gang. The bombing of the Merseburg restaurant injured 20 people, partly severly. Investigations focus on circles of organised crime, red-light milieu, and bikers.
Joyful swimming in Bavaria

The swimming bans implemented after the Whitsunday floods have mostly been removed. According to Health Minister Stamm, the situation has much improved. She said, test would give good results of the water quality. A swimming ban exists only for a few more lakes.
Steffi Graf in semi-final in Wimbledon

Steffi Graf reached the semi-final in the tennis tournaments of Wimbledon for the tenth time. Graf beat the American Venus Williams 6:3, 2:6 und 6:4. Graf will play the quarter-final against the winner of the match between the French Natalie Tauziat and the Kroat Lucic. With a win against the title holder Jana Novotna, the American Lindsay Davenport also qualified for the semi-finals.
Gold for Germany

The German equipe celebrates the 18th win in a sequence of the dressage world championships in Arnheim/The Netherlands. Gold medals went to Nadine Kapellmann, Alexandra Simonsderidder, Ulla Salzgeber and Isabel Wert. The Dutch team had, again, to be happy with the second place.
